div.div: Reviewed #1587 Added support to deactivate spack environments
Commented on #1587 Added support to deactivate spack environments

okay we need this to be a boolean type not an object can you please remove the properties it just needs to be a boolean. In the buildspec we have deactivate: true Right now your schema is setup to be something like this in yaml deactivate: name: true (1 more line was trimmed)
Commented on #1587 Added support to deactivate spack environments
please remove options there is no need for this when mapping options to spack env deactivate . Right now none of the options are useful
Reviewed #1587 Added support to deactivate spack environments

Merge branch 'how_to' into 'main'
production spack configuration documentation
See merge request NERSC/spack-infrastructure!97

My question is what is the best way to write modulefile that exposes MODULEPATH to a directory while removing the current directory that contains the modulefile nersc-modulefiles . I think the main issue is we have a recursion which has the following modulefile siddiq90@login01> cat /opt/nersc/pe/modulefiles/nersc-modulefiles/latest.lua help([[ (3 more lines were trimmed) Then in this MODULEPATH directory we have this same modulefile which points to itself siddiq90@login01> cat /global/common/software/nersc/pe/modulefiles/latest/nersc-modulefiles/latest.lua help([[ (3 more lines were trimmed) I think we have a recursion problem

I am now trying whether i can use remove_path to remove the path /opt/nersc/pe/modulefiles that didnt work same with append_path help([[ This modulefile will show expose the latest version of all modulefiles.(5 more lines were trimmed) I tried setenv that shows output for module av but when i loaded the module the value of MODULEPATH was empty so this cant work

Okay i figured out the problem we introduced a modulefile called nersc-modulefiles/latest that sets MODULEPATH to a directory which contains the same modulefiles that are rsync to shared filesystem which looks very almost exactly the same as the one in /opt/nersc/pe/modulefiles . The difference is that the one installed in /opt/nersc/pe/modulefiles are packaged as rpm and installed once per system maintenance. The ones rsync is done whenever we commit modulefiles to main branch in our modulefile repo. The whole point of this was to allow NERSC staff and users to be able to see the latest modulefiles before we release the new ones since they can't be used together i guess we either need to work around MODULEPATH because the one setup at startup needs to be removed when loading this module siddiq90@login01> cat nersc-modulefiles/latest.lua help([[ (3 more lines were trimmed)
Okay i confirmed this doesnt make any difference. I tested this locally siddiq90@login01> cd src/ siddiq90@login01> ls (30 more lines were trimmed)
I dont know if this makes any difference but there is a README.md file in the directory. Does that in any way cause Lmod to trip on other file extensions. /opt/nersc/pe/modulefiles/README.md
